levels.title: Why Strong Passwords Matter
cards: Many cyberattacks begin by guessing or cracking weak passwords.
Attackers use tools like brute-force and dictionary attacks to try thousands of password combinations quickly.
Passwords like '123456', 'admin', or 'password1' are in every attacker's playbook.

questions.question: Why is '123456' a weak password?
options: It is commonly used and easy to guess

questions.question: What is a brute-force attack?
options: Trying every possible combination until it works

levels.title: Components of a Strong Password
cards: A strong password uses uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special symbols.
Avoid using names, birthdays, or common words.
Good example: `P08%l1H#$a(kV17^` — it's long, random, and complex.

levels.title: Password Managers
cards: Password managers help create and store strong passwords securely.
They encrypt your credentials and require just one master password to access.
One example is LastPass, but most browsers also include built-in options.

questions.question: What is a password manager used for?
What should you do?
options: Use simple passwords so you don't forget them
Write them on a postit-note on your work desk
Use a Password Manager and strong passwords

levels.title: Never Share Your Password
cards: You should never share your passwords with anyone — not even friends or family.
Even if your friends don't have malicious intentions, they might fall prey to a cyberattack themselves, compromising you in the process.
Real companies and support teams will never ask for your password.
Social engineering is a tactic used by attackers to manipulate you into giving away sensitive information like passwords or even banking credentials
Examples include fake tech support calls, phishing emails, or someone pretending to be your teacher or boss. We will expand on this in a later chapter

questions.question: Who should you share your password with?
What is social engineering?
options: A method to strengthen social networks
A technique to guess passwords using tools
A way to trick people into revealing confidential information, like passwords

levels.title: Reusing Passwords
cards: Reusing the same password on multiple sites is risky. If one site gets hacked (aka a data breach), all your accounts using that password are at risk.
Use a different strong password for each account, or use a password manager to keep track of them safely.
If you hear about a data breach happening to an app or website you have an account on, change your password immediately.

questions.question: Why is it dangerous to reuse passwords?
options: It makes your accounts vulnerable if even one gets hacked

questions.question: What is a data breach?
options: Hackers getting access to a business's database, which can also hold your account information.
